Many people get dry eyes. It's not usually serious and there are things you can do to help.

sections.title: Causes of dry eyes
paragraphs: You can get dry eyes if you do not make enough tears or your tears dry up quickly.
You may be more likely to get dry eyes if:

sections.title: Do
paragraphs: clean your eyelids every day
take breaks to rest your eyes when watching TV or using a computer screen
make sure your computer screen is just below eye level
use a humidifier to stop the air getting dry
if you wear contact lenses, take them out and wear glasses to rest your eyes

sections.title: Don’t
paragraphs: do not smoke or drink too much alcohol
do not spend too long in smoky, dry or dusty places
do not spend too long in air conditioned or heated rooms
do not stop taking a prescribed medicine without getting medical advice first – even if you think it's causing your symptoms

sections.title: Non-urgent advice:See an optician or GP if:
paragraphs: They can check what the cause might be and recommend treatment for it.
If an optician or GP cannot find a cause, they may refer you to an eye specialist (ophthalmologist) for tests.

sections.title: Urgent advice:Ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
paragraphs: You can call 111 orget help from 111 online.

sections.title: Immediate action required:Call 999 or go to A&E if:
paragraphs: Do not drive to A&E. Ask someone to drive you or call 999 and ask for an ambulance.
Bring any medicines you take with you.
